pages.title: Learning Skills to Build Your Future
pages.content:
Hawaiian culture is rooted in mastery—learning important skills deeply and passing them on. In the past, survival depended on mastering things like canoe building, kalo (taro) farming, and fishing. Each ahupua‘a had kahuna and kumu (experts and teachers) who trained haumana (students) to take care of the land and people.

Training was intense. Students paid close attention, even studying by firelight late into the night. Whether it was learning every part of growing and making poi or crafting tools, this knowledge helped the community thrive.

Today, we still rely on learning skills to survive and succeed. We go to school, learn trades, apply for internships, or even start businesses. Like the haumana of the past, we each have a kuleana (responsibility) to build our skills, provide for our families, and pass our knowledge to future generations.

## Lesson Objectives

In this lesson, you will:

- Learn the 10 steps to finding and getting a job
- Discover what employee benefits are and which ones matter to you
- Explore community resources that can help with your job search
- Understand the paperwork you need to fill out when you get hired
- Learn what affects how much money you take home from your paycheck.
